Fields.DialogueText: Capitán, we are receiving reports of heavy mist nearby. It is possible there are Morganas in the area.
Any idea how many enemy vessels could be awaiting us?
No es importante, Capitán. These Brujas del Mar have yet to understand what it means to face me in combat. If they did, they would not dare approach.

Fields.MenuText: When I ask a question, I expect a clear answer, Canarias.
That is quite a bit of bravado there, Canarias. Are you sure you're not being overconfident?
Well said! It is time these Morganas learned to fear us!

Fields.DialogueText: Hmph. Very well, Capitán. Enemy numbers are unknown.
I am the flagship of the Spanish Fleet! I have never faced an enemy who could match me, and these Morganas shall prove no different!
¡Excelente! Together, we shall send these Morganas to the bottom of the sea!
All right then, send the crew to battle stations.
Very good, Capitán.
¡Atención! All hands to battle stations, prepare for action.
Take us forward, Canarias.
Sí, Capitán. Time to face your doom, Morganas.
@BATTLE
Capitán, my forward turret requires maintenance. I could feel the gears dragging during our last battle.
Why tell me? You can speak to the mechanics directly.
I have better things to do with my time than instruct the crew on how to do their job. Besides, the chain of command should be respected. You are their capitán.
You don't consider instructing the crew part of your duty?
My duty is to my capitán. You are the one I chose, not them.

Fields.MenuText: And if I order you to speak the mechanics directly?
Things will be a lot more efficient if you interact with the crew on your own initiative.
You may not have chosen them but they are here to fight just like you, and you should respect that.

Fields.DialogueText: If that is your order, then I shall carry it out.
Very well then, Capitán. In the future, I will work directly with the crew in routine matters.
I see... I will respect that they are a part of your crew, Capitán.
Good. I'll have a repair order put in.
Capitán, we have received word of a possible Morgana sighting, shall we go hunting?
Let's go.
@BATTLE
Canarias, what's that you're playing?
It is called a timple. It's a traditional guitar of the Canary Islands.
I meant what song are you playing.
You do not recognize it? It is Cara al Sol, the battle song of the Nationalists.
You were born during the Spanish Civil War, correct?
Sí, although my construction began at the hands of the Republicans, I was liberated by the Nationalists before my completion.
Civil war is always a horrible thing. It must have been hard for you to be born into such conflict.
Not at all, Capitán - I am proud of my service to España. I was able to push my country toward a brighter future. There is nothing horrible about that.
You don't regret being made to fire upon your own countrymen?
Anarchists and Communists are not my countrymen, Capitán! The Old Republic was corrupt and ineffective. The Republican ships I destroyed were a necessary sacrifice.

Fields.MenuText: Sometimes sacrifices must be made for the greater good.
Those who died were all sons and daughters of Spain. Regardless of their allegiance, their deaths are a tragedy.
That is a cold-hearted attitude, Canarias.

Fields.DialogueText: Exactamente. In the end, my actions brought about a stronger España. I regret nothing.
The real tragedy would have been letting them live. The Republic was a disease that would have destroyed all of España if it were allowed to continue.
Al contrario, Capitán. It is passion for an united, grand, and free España that fills my heart and leaves my conscience clean.
I see. So you did not empathize with the Republicans at all?
Never.
In that case, I am impressed you were so effective in combat. Being able to understand one's enemy is often the key to victory.
¿En serio? So you would seek to understand the Morganas?
Absolutely.
Well, it looks like you will have another opportunity. We have spotted an incoming enemy vessel!
@BATTLE
Capitán, Morganas sighted, approaching from the north.
Battle stations!
@BATTLE
That was some very effective shooting, Canarias.
¡Por supuesto, Capitán! They never had a chance against me.
They had the advantage of both range and firepower. Our victory was hardly assured.
Capitán, I am insulted! Certainly my cannons are not the largest on the sea, but what does the size of a blade matter when you press it to your enemy's throat?

Fields.MenuText: Careful, Canarias. Your confidence is beginning to smack of hubris.
Your aim is masterful, Canarias. But tactically, the ship with bigger guns will always have the advantage.
Really? Sounds like someone has some "cannon envy".

Fields.DialogueText: I know over thirty Republican ships that would disagree, Capitán. How is it that you still do not appreciate my full worth!?
The Brujas del Mar are welcome to underestimate me, but I thought you understood there is more to me than armament and tonnage.
¡¿Qué?! Capitán, how could you say something like that!?
Relax! Don't take it personally.
You are mistaken about me, Capitán! You should show more respect for your dueña de la nave.
Well, she certainly has her pride...
Canarias... Canarias! Stop trying to avoid me.
I am not avoiding you, Capitán. I am ignoring you.
Listen, I understand that I hurt your feelings, but we need to be a team. The fleet is depending on us.
I am listening, but I am not hearing an apology.
You think I owe you an apology?
Of course you do! Not only did you insult me, but even worse - you showed that you do not believe in me!

Fields.MenuText: What are you talking about? If I didn't believe in you, I wouldn't be on this ship!
I didn't mean to hurt your pride. You are an excellent ship and I am honored you chose me as your captain.
Enough! No more pouting. You are a flagship of the Spanish fleet! Act like it.

Fields.DialogueText: Do you really mean that, Capitán?
Do you really mean that, Capitán?
Do you really mean that, Capitán?
All right, Canarias.
I've received reports of Morgana activity not far from here. Feel up for a little search and destroy mission?
Always, Capitán. Always.
@BATTLE
Of course!
I want you to know I believe in you too, Capitán. That is why I was so insulted.
Of course!
Thank you, Capitán. It was not a choice I made lightly. Please remember that.
Of course!
¡Muy bien! Then as a flagship of the Spanish fleet, I will remind you to address me with proper respect in the future!
Ah, there is nothing like the rush of waves on the open sea. We're making excellent time, Canarias.
Gracias, Capitán. You will find me swift as well as powerful.
Your hull was based on a British design, correct? The County-class cruiser?
Hmph. It is true I was designed by the British, but I was built in España. I am a Spanish ship, and only a Spanish ship.
Sounds like you have a little resentment toward the English.
The Armada Española was once the greatest in the world. No one could stand before us, including the English pirates who raided our shipping lanes.
And now, England is considered the premier naval power.
Sí, Capitán. It is embarrassing to be a design copied from one's rival.

Fields.MenuText: The war between England and Spain was a long time ago. I don't think the two countries are really rivals anymore.
Well, think of it this way. You were designed by the premier naval power in the world and built by your countrymen. You have the best both countries can offer.
Copy or no, you're a fine ship, Canarias. I think you should be proud of your English heritage.

Fields.DialogueText: That just makes it worse, Capitán. The Spanish Navy is not even considered a match for the English.
Thank you, Capitán. Still, I would like to see España return to her rightful place, as the undisputed ruler of the waves.
I don't know about that, Capitán. Still, I am glad you recognize my fine design.
Well, at any rate, I guess the Morganas would be considered the premier fleet, nowadays.
Supongo que sí. In that case, the more Morganas I defeat, the greater glory I bring to España...
¡Venga, Capitán! Let us find more Brujas to crush. ¡Arriba España!
@BATTLE
¡Maldita sea! Every time I think I have one of those Brujas del Mar, they manage to slip away.
True. For whatever reason, sinking a Morgana permanently seems near impossible.
They may not be able to match me in open combat, but unless we can find a way to destroy these Morganas, this war may never end.
I can understand your frustration. I'm sure you miss Spanish waters.
Oh no, Capitán. The war in España is over. Without the Morganas, I would be sitting idly in port, or at best be patrolling the coastline. I am a warship. My place is on the battle line.
I do not want my enemies to think they can incur my wrath and survive.
I suppose you have never known peace, have you?
I was born into war. My cannons may bring peace to others, but it is not something I seek.
Don't tell me you're hoping Spain joins the war on land?
No me importa, Capitán. Even if Spain did join that war, the Morganas pose such a threat that I would likely be fighting them, regardless.
So you are neutral.
Don't misunderstand, Capitán. I remember my German and Italian allies, as well as the treachery of the Russians and French. However, I trust whatever decision General Franco makes.
You show a lot of faith in Francisco Franco.
And why shouldn't I? It was his guiding hand that brought unity and liberty to España.

Fields.MenuText: That hand has a lot of blood on it.
Liberty? I seem to recall Franco ending a Republic, not starting one.
That doesn't make him infallible.

Fields.DialogueText: The blood of the enemies of España, perhaps. It is the same blood I have on my own hands, Capitán. I do not think that makes me, or General Franco, a monster.
Living in anarchy and fear is not freedom. Because of General Franco, España is at peace, and her people are able to live their lives.
Verdad. But remember Capitán, I also show a lot of faith in you.
Mayday! Mayday! *garbled* unidentified vessel *garbled* need help immediately!
Canarias, get a fix on that signal and plot a course!
At once, Capitán. You won't escape me this time, Morgana...
@BATTLE
Capitán, I must speak with you immediately!
Canarias, what's wrong? Your face is completely red.
Robbery, Capitán! Insolence, insubordination, sabotage, mutiny!
Calm down, Canarias. Tell me what happened.
Key supplies have gone missing from the ship stores!
What supplies? Fuel, ammunition, fresh water?
Does it matter? What is important is that we have a thief onboard!
Canarias, why are you avoiding the question? What supplies?
Canarias?
... Bananas, Capitán.
Bananas!?
Sí, Capitán. A whole bunch of fresh bananas vanished overnight!

Fields.MenuText: Well, it certainly seems like you've gone bananas.
Bananas are hardly "key supplies," Canarias.
One bunch? Is this a joke? Why are you wasting my time with tales of vanishing fruit!

Fields.DialogueText: They... well... they were a personal supply, Capitán.
A personal supply? I think I can save you the trouble of hiring a detective. I seem to remember banana porridge in the mess hall this morning.
I, ah... I see. Forgive me for acting like such a fool, Capitán.
I didn't realize you liked bananas that much. In the future I'll make sure the cooks know to save you some.
I, uh... Gracias, Capitán. I would appreciate if you did not mention my outburst to the crew.
Of course. Now then, we have reports of Morganas nearby. Shall we get back to the war, Canarias?
Sí, Capitán.
@BATTLE
I am curious, Capitán, if you had been forced to choose between the Republicans or the Nationalists, which side would you have joined?
What makes you ask?
The vast majority of officers in the Republic Navy defected to the Nationalists at the outset of the war, even though the common sailors stayed loyal to the Republic.
You're asking if I would have done the same?
The quality of officers was a key difference between the two navies. I believe it was the main factor that contributed to Nationalist victory on the seas.
The quality of both officers and crew is important.
Perhaps, Capitán. But compared to the will of the shepherd, the braying of sheep is just noise.
Hmm... The question isn't really the same with the benefit of hindsight.
I suppose the real question is, are you a shepherd or one of the sheep?

Fields.MenuText: I think leadership comes naturally to me, if that is what you mean.
Being able to follow orders is just as essential for officers as it is for the crew. Discipline and loyalty are key traits for a captain. Does that make me a sheep?
One must learn to follow before one can lead. They are two sides of the same coin.

Fields.DialogueText: Very true, Capitán. Rank suits you.
No, I suppose not. It is clear to me that you are a leader, that is why I chose to follow you.
Interesante. You claim it is one in the same. But surely you are a more capable leader than most.
What about you, Canarias? Do you think of yourself as a shepherd or sheep?
Hmm... I have not thought about it...
Capitán, enemy Morgana detected!
Canarias, prepare for battle!
@BATTLE
Capitán, I have been thinking about what you asked me... if I was a shepherd or a sheep.
And?
I did not seem to quite fit into either category until I realized, I am Canarias.
Well, I could have told you that.
No, I mean, I am named after the Canary Islands. In Latin, the name means "island of the dogs." I am neither shepherd nor sheep. I am a sheepdog.
A sheepdog?
Sí, Capitán. I assist you in order to guide the flock, just as I am loyal to General Franco in order to guide my country.

Fields.MenuText: I don't know, you seem like more of a wolf than a sheepdog to me.
I wouldn't call you a dog, but I have come to depend on you.
This is getting out of hand. You are a warship, not a dog, Canarias.

Fields.DialogueText: Una loba del mar? Perhaps so, I am a hunter among the waves.
I am glad to hear you say so, Capitán.
A warship? Pues sí, Capitán. Not one for metaphor, are you?
So what does all that mean, Canarias?
It means you have my loyalty and support, Capitán, now and always. Como un perro.
Incoming message from the fleet, Morganas sighted. Shall we, Capitán?
After you, Canarias.
@BATTLE
Canarias, what are you doing out here?
Look to our bow, Capitán.
A pod of seals. They seem to enjoy swimming alongside you.
I welcome their company. They remind me of the monk seals of the Canary Islands.
Have you ever been to the Canary Islands?
Only once after victory in España. It was the islanders who presented me with my official combat flag. However, I know much of the history and culture of the islands.

Fields.MenuText: Maybe you can live on the Islands once this is all over.
It is sad that you have only seen your home once.
You seem to have a soft spot for those Islands.

Fields.DialogueText: I am a Belle, Capitán, I will never be able to live on land. Island or otherwise.
The islands are not my home. I am happy enough on the open sea.
I have an interest in my namesake, nothing more.
All the same, I can tell the islands are special to you.
Capitán, off on the horizon, I believe we have a Morgana approaching.
@BATTLE
The seals... the cannon fire must have scared them away.
Capitán, may I speak with you a moment?
Of course, Canarias. Please, come in.
I am concerned about our crew, Capitán. Are you sure they can be trusted?
I have seen no reason for concern, do you suspect trouble?
I could not help but overhear some of our sailors talking after our last battle. Their conversation indicated a dangerous inclination toward Bolshevism.
You know our crew is international. I'm sure there are many different political ideologies among them.
And this does not concern you?

Fields.MenuText: We have a common enemy in the Morganas, it would be foolish for any crew member to create division in the face of such a dangerous foe.
My crew's beliefs are their own business. So long as they follow orders, they can believe whatever they like.
You won't be starting another civil war on my ship. You need to learn to work with the crew regardless of whether or not you agree with them.

Fields.DialogueText: That is a naive attitude, Capitán. It is because we have a dangerous foe that we must be on guard. After all, what better time for a Bolshevik to strike than when we are distracted?
Even if those beliefs include a desire to create anarchy and destruction aboard the ship?
A navy can not operate if sailors do not follow orders. I have never known a communist to respect proper authority.
Enough, Canarias. You are only planting seeds of division.
There can be no unity with provocadores among our crew.
Excuse me, Captain. Sorry to interrupt, but we have Morganas sighted.
Very well. We will speak more later, Canarias, until then you will cooperate with all our crew members, including the communists. Is that understood?
Sí, Capitán.
@BATTLE
There is our transport, Captain, but no signs of her attacker.
Are we still receiving an S.O.S. signal?
Yes, Captain. There must be survivors onboard.
I cannot detect any Morganas, Capitán, but they are still here. I am sure of it.
Captain! Torpedoes in the water!
Evasive action!
You think to sink me, Bruja del Mar! You shall learn what it means to face a Canarias-class heavy cruiser!
@BATTLE
¡Victoria, Capitán!

Fields.MenuText: Yes, but a costly one.
We should have saved the transport!
Good work, Canarias. We have taken our revenge.

Fields.DialogueText: ¿Qué? Ah yes, the transport. Some sacrifices are unavoidable.
Her fate was sealed before we arrived. Trying to save her would only have allowed our enemy to escape.
Let the Morganas remember the name Canarias next time they seek easy prey in these waters!
Begin the search for survivors. Perhaps we can still save some from the waves.
Baleares...
Lone Morgana sighted, Capitán. Moving to engage.
Only one ship? Something isn't right. Where there's one...
Firing cannons!
@BATTLE
Damage report.
Our damage control teams have things under control, Captain. Repairs are already underway.
Good. Canarias, I'd like to speak to you. Now.
If this is about my failure to spot the additional Morganas, I am limited by the equipment available to me.
Your ability is not in question, Canarias, your respect for command is. You engaged without orders.
I was anticipating your orders, Capitán. Should I hold fire in the face of the enemy!?

Fields.MenuText: You should hold fire until I give the order!
It seems you failed to anticipate I might use caution when faced with a possible ambush.
You played right into our enemies' hands.

Fields.DialogueText: I am a warship, not a member of your crew. I chose you as my capitán, and that doesn't make me your servant.
So I should proceed under the assumption that you will be meek in the face of danger?
We won, didn't we?
You gave the enemy a tactical advantage, you put yourself and your crew in danger, and failed to respect my command. That is completely unacceptable.
So, you do care about discipline and order aboard your ship? Then start by dealing with the agitators in your crew! Not by berating the Belle who is loyal to you!
Canarias...
If you were a member of my crew I would consider a court martial for insubordination.
It was not my judgment that put this crew in danger. It was yours.
That justifies nothing. If we're going to win this war it will be because we fight it on our terms, not because we give the enemy every advantage before a fight.
I thought I might find you out here. I can't see below the waves in this light. Are there seals alongside us?
No, Capitán, it is just us here.
It seems we still have a lot to talk about...
I should not have fired without orders, Capitán. The chain of command must always be respected.
Indeed. However, I was referring to our discussion about dissidents within the crew. Has it ever occurred to you that I might be a communist?
You, Capitán? No, that is impossible, I have seen the way you take command. You take decisive action, this ship is not run by committee or anarchy.

Fields.MenuText: In war, a single voice is needed during the chaos of battle, but that doesn't mean I believe a country should be lead the same way.
There are plenty of nations with differing political ideologies in this war. All of them have captains.
Of course it is possible. Being a leader doesn't automatically make me a fascist.

Fields.DialogueText: True unity requires a single voice.
Sí, but that is just evidence that a strong voice is needed.
However, the best leaders naturally rise up to light the way forward for those around them.
So then, what do you believe, Capitán?
It doesn't matter.
¿Perdóname?
It doesn't matter because I am committed to defeating the Morganas, and I am committed to working with all nations and peoples to do it. I would like you to commit to the same.
I will work with them, Capitán. But I cannot trust them.
*sigh* Well, I suppose that is a start.
We are receiving a new transmission from the fleet. There are Morganas in the area.
All right, let's get to it.
@BATTLE
But that voice must come from all people, not just the leader.
It is also evidence that communist crews are just as capable of following orders as everyone else.
Or to blanket the people in darkness.
We have reports of fog in the nearby area, Capitán. Shall we change course?
Tactically, it conceals the Morganas' movements from our reconnaissance planes. Still, I wonder what the deeper relationship is between these ghosts ships and the fog.
I am not sure, Capitán. It is possible they have been using fog to conceal their activities from mankind for centuries.
Hmm... the myth of Charybdis, the Kamikaze, even what Olaus Magnus wrote about the Mokstraumen. I suppose it could all be what we now call Morganas.
Do not forget the destruction of the Grande y Felicísima Armada.
Yes, twice the English found victory in the face of overwhelming odds due to a freak storm.
Those pirates should have faced the righteous retribution of España for their crimes.
The English labelled the storm "The Protestant Wind." They claimed it was proof that their cause against Spain was just.
There was nothing "just" about English piracy. However, clearly, it was God's will that the English escape their punishment.

Fields.MenuText: So you believe in God then?
Technology and tactics saved the English, not supernatural nonsense.
Oh? I thought you said the Spanish were in the right? Why would God allow a righteous cause to fail?

Fields.DialogueText: Sí, Capitán. I believe in the teachings of the Holy Catholic Church.
Capitán, do not be so cynical. There is much more to life than what we can see and touch.
God's ways are not for us to understand. There are times when wickedness is allowed to triumph in this life, but justice will always come in the next.
Do you think the Morganas are an act of God?
No, Capitán. God is on our side. Allow me to engage these Morganas, and I will prove it to you.
@BATTLE
Capitán! There is a fire in our port turbine room!
Get fire control teams on sight immediately! Canarias?
Fire control responding, situation is under control. Uh... Captain? I'm being told there is a fight going on in the turbine room.
A fight?
Admit it! You set this fire intentionally to keep me from pursuing the Morganas!
She's crazy! Watch out!
Canarias! Put that down!
But Capitán, they are saboteurs!
That is a serious charge, do you have any evidence?
Evidence? They just lit a fire in the turbine room while we were distracted in battle! What more evidence do you need!?
It's not true, Captain. It was impact from one of the enemy shells that splashed nearby. It caused the wiring to come loose. It was the sparks that started the fire.

Fields.MenuText: Canarias, you are out of line! Stand down immediately!
A loose wire, eh? It could be true, or it could be a convenient cover story.
All right then, let's everyone calm down. We won't get to the truth by throwing around accusations.

Fields.DialogueText: Capitán! How can you say this! Clearly, that is a lie!
I told you they were guilty! Let me have them, Capitán, I will see that they meet their justice at the end of my cannons!
What accusations!? Look at them, Capitán, their guilt is written all over their faces.
There will be an official inquiry as to the cause of the fire. Until that time, no formal accusations will be made, and no preemptive punishment given.
You are letting them get away with this!?
That's enough, Canarias! I have made my decision.
¡Increíble!
*ALARM*
I suppose the Morganas will get off with nothing more than a slap on the hull as well.
@BATTLE
Finally, after thorough investigation, we have determined that it was the impact of enemy shells, and not intentional tampering, that caused the fire.
Indeed, our turbine crew is to be commended for their swift response to the fire. That concludes our investigation. Now, let's return to our duties and get this ship underway.
Yes, Captain!
So. No evidence of sabotage? How can you believe that, Capitán? I see the looks the crew give me when they think I am not looking, they can barely hide their contempt.
You are right about there being a saboteur aboard. But she was not in the turbine room when the fire started.
I knew it! Who is she, Capitán? I will lash this traitor to our bow.
You might want to reconsider that. You're the saboteur, Canarias.
Capitán! This is not a joke, we are in real danger!
I'm not joking. This witch hunt of yours has destroyed morale and cost us precious time we could have used fighting Morganas. What would you call that?
But, it is clear they despise me, Capitán. They are socialists, communists, anarchists, they could never trust a Belle who respects order and discipline.

Fields.MenuText: The crew respects order and discipline just fine. It's my Belle who is stirring up division and chaos.
Listen to yourself! If they despise you, you only have yourself to blame. You have never respected the crew, why should they trust you?
More often than not we see what we expect to see. Expect our crew to hold you in contempt, and that is what you will see. But don't blame them for your paranoia.

Fields.DialogueText: I am only trying to protect myself, to protect you, Capitán!
I thought I had your trust, Capitán, how can you take their side over mine?
It is not paranoia! You are too trusting, Capitán, you are blind to the dangers they pose.
Stop. This is not about you and me, this about you and our crew, because they aren't just my crew, Canarias. They are our crew, and until you accept that, you sabotage us all.
Now then, it's long past time we returned to the war. I can't order you to apologize, Canarias, but either you fight with our crew, or you can sit this one out.
... I will fight, Capitán.
@BATTLE
Excuse me, Captain. Compliments of the chef.
Is this banana pudding? I hope you saved some for Canarias.
Actually, Canarias asked the cook to prepare it for the whole crew.
She did? How many bananas do we have left?
None. She had us use them all. Do you think she is trying to apologize?

Fields.MenuText: Well, it's a step in the right direction.
I think she owes the crew a bit more than a few bananas.
I know how much she loves her bananas. I think we can interpret this as an apology.

Fields.DialogueText: Yes, Captain. I'll return to my duties.
Forgiveness is a two-way street. I think you might be surprised by what the crew thinks of you.
Excuse me again, Captain - oh, and Canarias. We have reports of Morganas nearby.
Very well. Let's get to it, Canarias.
@BATTLE
Do you like the pudding, Capitán?
Canarias? How long have you been here?
Yes, Captain. I'll return to my duties.
Do you like the pudding, Capitán?
Canarias? How long have you been here?
Yes, Captain. I'll return to my duties.
Do you like the pudding, Capitán?
Canarias? How long have you been here?
I heard what you said. I want the crew to understand I regret the damage my accusations have caused. I am not sure how to put that into words.
I heard what you said. I know banana pudding is not a proper apology, Capitán, but I am not sure how else to give one.
I heard what you said. I'm glad you understand what I am trying to tell the crew, Capitán. I just hope they understand the gesture as well.
I thought I heard your timple. Is that Francisco Tárrega?
I'm impressed, Capitán. Sí, this is Recuerdos de la Alhambra.
I had to ask one of the crew, to be honest. You are quite talented. Have you ever considered giving a concert?
I play to focus my mind, Capitán, not to entertain.
That's too bad. I'm sure the crew would love to hear you play. I certainly do.
Do you think I am too harsh, Capitán?

Fields.MenuText: What are you talking about? Where did that come from?
You certainly can be stubborn, but I like that about you.
Well, yeah. You have a few rough edges to you.

Fields.DialogueText: We seem to have a lot of arguments. I do not wish for their to be resentment between us.
I... I am glad to hear you say this, Capitán. Please do not think my stubbornness means I do not respect you.
Tiene razón, Capitán. But, I hope that is not all you see.
We may have our disagreements, but I am fighting alongside you because I want to be.
Excuse me, Captain...
Don't tell me, more Morganas?
Yes, Captain.
This war certainly doesn't leave much time for music does it, Canarias?
Está bien, Capitán. I will have plenty of time to play once we show these Morganas what we're made of.
@BATTLE
Scout planes report an incoming Morgana fleet.
Captain, we are receiving a radio transmission. I... I think it is coming from a Morgana.
Let's hear it.
You... you will fall... you are weak... you are insignificant... you will serve... or you will die...
Can we triangulate the position of that signal?
No need, Captain. It looks like they're headed straight for us.
You... the one called Canarias... you are mine to break...

Fields.MenuText: It knows your name!?

Fields.DialogueText: ¡Nave diabla! How... how dare you! Full speed ahead!
Canarias, wait!
@BATTLE
They're retreating! We made it!
Canarias! Canarias say something!
Capitán... I... I am sorry... I feel a bit faint...
Canarias!

Fields.MenuText: Send no reply.
Canarias, don't let them provoke you.

Fields.DialogueText: If they hope this intimidates me, it certainly does not!
Aye-aye, Captain. We'll keep quiet.
My blood is boiling...
How are you feeling?
I'm feeling much better, Capitán.
You still look weak. Are you sure?
Capitán, you still haven't told me. How many did we lose?

Fields.MenuText: The fight cost us a few good men and women.
That's not important right now. Focus on regaining your strength.
Losses are unavoidable in war.

Fields.DialogueText: It was my fault. I disobeyed you again. I failed you and them.
It is important, Capitán! I was responsible for their deaths, how can I focus on anything else!?
I know I cannot undo what I have done, Capitán. I will understand if you cannot forgive me.
We survive by moving on, by admitting our faults and learning from them. You want to respect our fallen comrades? Acknowledge them, honor them, and keep fighting.
... Capitán, I... Gracias, Capitán.
Capitán. We have entered enemy waters.
Are you sure you are up for this?
I am. Please, Capitán. I will not recover unless I hear the roar of my cannons. The Brujas del Mar also have much to answer for.
@BATTLE
Capitán! Torpedoes in the water!
Hard to starboard! Canarias, give me everything you can!
@BATTLE
Well, that's the end of that.
The crew fought bravely, Capitán.
As did you, Canarias. I think it is safe to say you have recovered.
Capitán, there is something I would like to speak to you about.
What's this about, Canarias?
Capitán, are you familiar with the Baleares?
Your sister ship? The only other Canarias-class cruiser. She was sunk during the civil war, yes?
Sí, sunk by Republican torpedoes. I saw it all, but could do nothing to save her.
I want you to know, Capitán. All I could think about while fighting today was my sister. I couldn't stop thinking I would join her.

Fields.MenuText: That is nothing to be ashamed of, Canarias. It is natural to feel fear during a battle.
The Baleares didn't have me as her captain. I promise I won't allow you to share her fate.
I was afraid, too, Canarias. That doesn't make either of us a coward.

Fields.DialogueText: I didn't understand fear before. Now I don't know if it will ever leave me.
Gracias, Capitán. But not even you could have saved her. I can't stop thinking it will be the same for me.
You were afraid, Capitán? If you can fight the way you do while you are afraid, perhaps I can learn to live with fear as well.
Good. Being fearless isn't the same thing as being brave. Fear is the first step to bravery, and I can say without reservation that you fought bravely today, Canarias.
I fought... bravely?
You didn't let your fear control you, and you put your duty ahead of your own safety. I am proud of you, Canarias.
¡Muchas gracias, Capitán! I am proud to be your Belle, and I promise to fight at your side, until I can fight no more.
Now then, we should rejoin the crew. There is more work to be done.
What's going on?
Shh! Oh, I'm sorry, Captain! I didn't realize it was you.
Canarias is putting on a concert for the crew.

Fields.MenuText: It's beautiful. Uh... what is it?
Wait, who is left on the bridge?
Canarias invited the whole crew to listen to her play?

Fields.DialogueText: Romance Anonimo, Captain. A fine example of Spanish guitar.
Don't worry, Captain. The ship is still staffed, just those us off duty are on the deck. The rest of the crew is listening over the loudspeaker.
Well, she was just going to play in sick bay, but when she realized the whole crew wanted to listen, she had us move the injured to the deck so everyone could hear.
Ah, good.
She plays like an angel.
Thank you. Gracias.
*Applause* Bravo! Encour! Fantástico! Magnifique!
All hands, enemy Morgana spotted heading our direction. Ship profile matches Sabotage.
Listen to me, comrades! This Morgana has challenged us before, and though the price was high, together we defeated her. She returns because we are a threat she cannot ignore!
Last time we fought divided, my own actions putting many of you at risk. Today, I promise our capitán and each one of you, that we fight together, undivided and unafraid!
Today our enemy will see the full power and ferocity of this crew unleashed! Today we show her this is our sea, and no matter what terror she brings, she will not take it from us!
*Cheers* Huzzah! Let's show 'em! Payback!
Well said, Canarias.
Incoming Morganas! Clear the decks and get to battle stations!
@BATTLE
Capitán! You are just in time! Look, the seals have returned!
I'm glad to have them back.
We have come a long way, but they are still by our side.
We still have a long way to go, but I think they'll be waiting for us at the end.
I wanted to thank you again, Capitán. Your words have meant a great deal to me.
You're one heck of a Belle, Canarias. I'm honored to be your captain.
Capitán... it is I who am honored to be your Belle. It makes my heart feel right.

Fields.MenuText: The Morganas won't stand a chance against the two of us, Captain and Belle.
My heart feels the same way, Canarias.

Fields.DialogueText: I couldn't have said it better myself.
Oh! Maybe I can think of a song to play, if you have a little bit of time.
Sounds perfect, Canarias.
